urn:contentItem:530S-KGC1-DYRH-B1R5-00000-00Fire Brigades Union Praise Efforts of Fire Crews at Swinley Forest Fire2011-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisFire Brigades Union Praise Efforts of Fire Crews at Swinley Forest Fire

BERKSHIRE, ENGLAND--(Marketwire - June 2, 2011) - The Fire Brigades Union have paid tribute to the work of firefighters and emergency control room staff who went the extra mile to fight and manage the Swinley Forest fire. Hundreds of FBU members worked extremely long and arduous shifts to achieve a successful conclusion to this unprecedented incident.

The FBU also notes the dangers posed by woodland fires and their environmental and financial cost. It urges Royal Berkshire Fire Authority to delay the implementation of Bracknell Forest Area Fires Partnership Trial until a full review of the Swinley Forest fire has been completed and lessons learnt. This policy, due for implementation on 1st June 2011, sees the management of small woodland fires handed over to designated park rangers in the Bracknell Forest area.

The FBU is also concerned by plans to implement the Low Risk Incidents Policy that includes such fires. The policy will use full-time fire engines to respond to low risk calls on part-time station areas rather than the nearest available fire engine.

Maurice Whyte, Berkshire FBU Brigade Chair, said:

"Berkshire's crews and many others from as far away as Gloucestershire and Northamptonshire assisted with the incident and emergency fire control staff tirelessly co-ordinated the response of hundreds of crews, officers and supporting resources. Their work was nothing less than outstanding and they should be congratulated on their efforts in extremely testing circumstances".

"The recent incident at Swinley Forest stretched Royal Berkshire Fire and Rescue Service resources to their utmost and diluted fire cover in Berkshire with reduced attendances at other incidents. We are concerned that the new policies such as the Bracknell Forest Area Fires Partnership and the Low Risk Incident Policy will leave Berkshire vulnerable to the impact of large forest fires in future. Every fire is small at the outset but it is foolish to delay dealing with it. Not using the nearest fire engine would be such a delay".

urn:contentItem:5399-82B1-DYTJ-12BC-00000-00Forest fire knocks out power to three northern Ontario communities2011-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisQUEBEC-ONTARIO REGIONAL NEWSForest fire knocks out power to three northern Ontario communitiesCP

DRYDEN, Ont. _ A forest fire burning outside the northern Ontario community of Ear Falls has consumed power lines that feed Pickle Lake, Cat Lake First Nation and Mishkeegogamang.

Hydro One says the power went out around 3:30 p.m. Sunday in the three communities and it could be Friday at the earliest when power is restored.

Hydro One spokeswoman Danielle Gauvin says crews haven't been able to properly access the damage.

Officials in Pickle Lake have been forced to scramble to find generators to maintain essential services.

Residents in Sandy Lake, Cat Lake, North Spirit Lake, Keewaywin and Koocheching First Nations are on evacuation alert as smoke drifts in from four forest fires in the area.

British Columbia is sending 93 people to help with the firefighting efforts _ including 30 three-person initial attack crews.

The crews, along with three officials of B.C.'s wildfire management branch, will be leaving on Tuesday. All associated costs will be covered by Ontario.

Firefighters have been making progress on the blazes, officials with Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources said. The fires are not threatening the First Nation communities, they said.

Meanwhile, 543 Deer Lake residents remain in Greenstone after being evacuated from their community because of thick smoke from nearby forest fires. (CKDR, The Canadian Press)

STONY RAPIDS, Sask. _ A fast-moving forest fire fuelled by hot, dry winds was bearing down on two remote communities in northern Saskatchewan, forcing more than 200 people to flee their homes.

RCMP Sgt. Carole Raymond said as of Sunday evening, the fire was less than three kilometres from Stony Rapids and Stony Lake, which are fly-in communities near the boundary with the Northwest Territories.

It's the second time this month that people in the area had to leave their homes due to a forest fire.

Prisoners from the local RCMP detachment and most of the elderly and those with health problems were flown out, and some residents drove to Black Lake, about 90 minutes southeast, Raymond said.

But the road ends there, and the only way to get out of Black Lake is to fly.

By Sunday night, officials were expecting more than 200 people would be in Prince Albert, Sask., more than 800 kilometres south of their homes.

RCMP started going door-to-door early Sunday afternoon telling residents to gather their pets and belongings when the fire was just six kilometres east of town.

Judy Orthner, director of communications for the Ministry of Corrections, Public Safety and Policing, said 200 people were being flown to Prince Albert, Sask., and will be housed at the Saskatchewan Institute of Applied Science and Technology campus.

''It's a large campus and there will be dormitory space there because fortunately all the students are home for summer vacation,'' Orthner said.

She said there will be medical assessments done on people and they will transported to medical facilities if necessary.

Val Nicholson, communications consultant with the Saskatchewan Ministry of the Environment, said firefighters and water tankers from the Northwest Territories came Sunday to help out.

Fire crews were also using foam and retardant at the west side of the Stony Rapids to try to stop the fire's progress.

However, hot, dry weather wasn't helping, and the forecast for the next few days was for more of the same.

''They had no precipitation to speak of for some time and temperatures are quite high and we're dealing with a pretty strong sustained wind from the west, all of which are making it pretty difficult.

''The conditions are pretty challenging.''

Fire crews were also setting up sprinklers on homes and buildings and using heavy equipment to cut fire lines to try to save the communities, Nicholson said.

''We're all hoping.''

Earlier this month, about 70 elderly and sick people were moved out of the communities as a precaution due to smoke from a forest fire.

The Ritchie fire has burned about 400 square kilometres of land. Nicholson said the fire now threatening the communities is part of the Ritchie fire.

''What happened a couple of days ago a fire from the original fire spotted about 20 kilometres west of the community of Stony Rapids, and we actioned that immediately, but with the little rain and the dry conditions that we have up there it's been very difficult.''

_ By Mary Jo Laforest in Edmonton

SANDIE RINALDO: Another environmental crisis in British Columbia is forcing residents to run for their lives. A huge forest fire is raging out of control near Slocan in the province's southeast Kootenay region. More than 30 homes have been evacuated and another 60 are threatened. Fire lines are holding as unpredictable winds whip up the flames, but officials warn the situation could quickly change. CTV's St. John Alexander is on the front lines of this fire fight.

ST. JOHN ALEXANDER *****: It is a stubborn fire. Conditions are hot and dry, and firefighters admit they are having a hard time putting it out. At the base of the mountain lays the tiny village of Slocan. Every morning residents look up to see how far it spread.

CHARLENE STRELAEFF (Slocan Resident): I was just wondering which way the winds were going to blow and whether or not it was going to come this way or if it was going to proceed up the mountain.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: I don't know, it's kind of scary I guess.

ALEXANDER: The busiest place in town is here, the fire camp. It is up to these people to predict where the flames will go next.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN: I just came home from work the other night and all of a sudden there was a little army town in the (inaudible).

ALEXANDER: Overnight it spread another 1,500 hectares. The flames so fierce they crossed over the local highway. It remains closed until further notice.

CATHY PRYOR (Slocan Resident): It's very smoky in my house last night.

ALEXANDER: Cathy Pryor runs the local coffee shop. Her home is somewhere up on this hill. She's been told she may have to leave at a moment's notice.

PRYOR: The fire is far away now, but if a storm came you never know where the fire will be next.

ALEXANDER: For now one of the greatest concerns is this bridge. It is the link between Slocan and other towns. Crews are using sprinklers to keep it wet and stop it from burning. Firefighters say they had a good day and are getting the upper hand, but there was a chance of thunderstorms in the forecast which could spark even more fires. urn:contentItem:5JPV-0GB1-JBVR-34M5-00000-00Forest fire location, not necessarily size, priority for battling blazes2016-05-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisNATIONALForest fire location, not necessarily size, priority for battling blazesFire location, not necessarily size, importantJennifer GrahamThe Canadian Press

Whipped up by wind and fuelled by tinder dry conditions, the wildfire in Fort McMurray, Alta., grew to about 1,000 square kilometres on Friday.

An expert said it's a dangerous fire because of its location, not necessarily because of its size.

"Let's put this into perspective. That is a high-priority area," said Marc Mousseau of the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre in Winnipeg.

"If you get a fire on the Saskatchewan-Manitoba-Nunavut border, that thing could be 300,000 hectares (3,000 square kilometres) and nobody would even know because there's nobody up there and it's zero priority."

Mousseau said that's why the size of a fire isn't always the most important factor in setting firefighting priorities.

"Is it a large fire that caused a lot of concern or is it a large fire in the middle of nowhere that's roaming around for three months and they're tracking it with satellites? In other words, they're not even looking at it."

Mousseau uses the so-called Great Miramichi Fire of 1825 as an example. It's estimated that the fire destroyed about 12,000 square kilometres in northern New Brunswick. At least 160 people were killed.

In 2011, a fire destroyed about 7,000 square kilometres in northern Alberta. The Richardson backcountry fire was about 60 kilometres north of Fort McMurray and has been described as the largest fire in Alberta's modern history.

But Mousseau suggests it may have slipped under the radar for the public because it happened at the same time as a devastating fire in Slave Lake, Alta.

The Slave Lake fire only covered about 47 square kilometres, but forced more than 10,000 to flee the community. One-third of Slave Lake, more than 500 homes and buildings, including the town hall, were damaged or destroyed.

A report prepared by consulting firm KPMG on the Slave Lake fire said: "Everyone was caught off guard by how fast the fires advanced with this wind behind them."

On its website, the B.C. Wildfire Service lists large wildfires, including the fire in the Kelowna area in 2003.

The Okanagan Mountain Park fire was more than 250 square kilometres. It forced 33,050 people out of their homes, mostly in Kelowna, and nearly 240 homes were lost or damaged. Three firefighters were killed.

The service describes it as "the most significant interface wildfire event in B.C. history," interface being the area where people and the forest meet.

(CP) - City officials have lifted the state of emergency declared last week after a forest fire jumped a river and burned dangerously close to Timmins.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire was "declared under control this morning,'' said Ben Legouffe, spokesman for Ontario's Natural Resources Ministry. "It looks pretty good.''</p><p>The fire, which hit its peak Thursday, forced the temporary evacuation of 400 residents - most of them from trailer parks on the outskirts of the city.</p><p>Meanwhile, burning permits within the city's limits have been revoked by fire Chief Lester Cudmore.</p><p>With more warm weather in the forecast, conditions across Northern Ontario remain hazardous with provincial officials saying the risk of more fires is extreme.</p><p>"It's good for holidaying but not for forest fires,'' said Legouffe. "The (fire) hazard will creep up during the week.''</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters in northwestern Ontario - more than 9,000 kilometres away - have slowed the advance of a forest fire near Kenora.</p><p>The Natural Resources Ministry has warned people not to light campfires or burn garbage in the area.</p><p>Seventeen firefighters were needed to halt a 96-hectare fire that broke out Saturday northwest of the city, said Mitch Miller, a fire information officer.</p><p>No homes were lost and the few residents evacuated briefly Saturday were allowed to return home that evening.</p><p>"We've had between six and nine fires each day for the past week,'' Miller said Sunday. "Daytime heating continues to be a worry and the threat of thunder showers is building.''</p><p>Lightning strikes are expected to start more fires.</p><p>"If a lightning storm comes through, we could see a hundred fires in a day.''</p><p>There were 23 new fires reported in the province from Friday to Sunday, most of them in nortwestern Ontario.</p><p>Firefighters were working to control 15 fires covering 600 hectares, the Provincial Fire Centre reported today. Four waterbombers - two from Quebec and two from the Northwest Territories - were called in to help.</p><p>"An increase in lightning-caused fires is expected,'' the centre said in a statement.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier A1Portugal in mourning after deadly infernoAt least 62 people killed, many trapped in their cars as they tried to flee fast-moving forest fireHelena Alves and Armando Franca The Associated PressPEDROGAO GRANDE, PORTUGAL

A raging forest fire in central Portugal killed at least 62 people as they desperately tried to flee, charring cars and trucks as it swept over roads. The disaster - the worst tragedy Portugal has experienced in decades - shook the nation, with the president declaring that the country's pain "knows no end."

Almost 24 hours after the deaths Saturday night, fires were still churning across the forested hillsides of central Portugal. Police and firefighters were searching charred areas of the forest and isolated homes, looking for more bodies.

"It is a time of pain but also ... a time to carry on the fight" against the flames, President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa told the nation in a televised address Sunday evening after the government declared three days of national mourning.

A huge wall of thick smoke and bright red flames towered over the tops of trees in the forested Pedrogao Grande area, 150 kilometres northeast of Lisbon, where a lightning strike was believed to have sparked the blaze Saturday. Investigators found a tree that was hit during a "dry thunderstorm," the head of the national judicial police said.

Dry thunderstorms are frequent when high temperatures cause falling water to evaporate before reaching the ground.

Portugal is prone to forest fires in the dry summer months, and temperatures as high as 40 C hit the affected area in recent days.

At least four other significant wildfires were burning Sunday elsewhere in Portugal, but the one in Pedrogao Grande was responsible for all the deaths.

"The dimensions of this fire have caused a human tragedy beyond any in our memory," Prime Minister Antonio Costa told reporters as he arrived at the scene Sunday.

"Something extraordinary has taken place and we have to wait for experts to properly determine its causes."

Interior Minister Constanca Urbano de Sousa said the death toll had risen to 62 by the end of Sunday. She said the country's judicial police were expecting to complete the identification of the bodies soon in order to release them as early as possible.

Interior Ministry official Jorge Gomes said firefighting crews were having difficulty battling the fire, which was "very intense" in at least two of its four fronts. He said authorities were worried about strong winds that could help spread the blaze further.

More than 350 soldiers on Sunday joined the 700 firefighters who have been struggling to put out the blaze, schools in the area were closed until further notice and outdoor fires were banned.

The forest fire deaths were the biggest in memory in Portugal, which saw 25 Portuguese soldiers die fighting wildfires in 1966. Last August, an outbreak of fires across Portugal killed four people, including three on the island of Madeira, and destroyed huge areas of forest.

Isabel Brandao told The Associated Press on Sunday that she had feared for her life when she saw the Pedrogao Grande blaze.

"Yesterday, we saw the fire but thought it was very far. I never thought it would come to this side," she said. "At 3:30 a.m., my mother-in-law woke me up quickly and we never went to sleep again."

Others were also shocked.

"This is a region that has had fires because of its forests, but we cannot remember a tragedy of these proportions," said Valdemar Alves, the mayor of Pedrogao Grande. "I am completely stunned by the number of deaths."

Broadcaster RTP showed terrifying images of several people on a road trying to escape the intense smoke that had reduced visibility to a few meters. A young man shared a bottle of water with a distraught woman as she stumbled down the road.

Gomes gave a grim description of the deaths to RTP. He said at least 30 people died inside their cars as they tried to flee between the towns of Figueiro dos Vinhos and Castanheira de Pera. He said 17 others died right outside their cars or by the road, 11 people died in the forest, two people died in a car accident related to the fire and information was missing on the other deaths.

Gomes said 54 people were also injured in the fire, 5 of them seriously, including four firefighters and a child.

Costa tweeted his "deepest regret for the victims . . . and a word of encouragement and strength for all who help combat this scourge."

"We are most likely facing the biggest tragedy of human life that we have known," he said.

There was no immediate identification of the victims. Portugal established a special diplomatic channel for embassies to receive information on foreign citizens who "may be affected."

The European Union responded to a call for assistance by Portugal. As a result, Spain sent four firefighting aircraft on Sunday, France was sending three and Greece's prime minister also offered firefighting help.

Many world leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, Pope Francis and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressed solidarity with Portugal. Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy tweeted that he was "overwhelmed by the tragedy at Pedrogao Grande. The Portuguese people can count on our solidarity, support and care."

In Kazan, Russia, Portugal's national soccer team wore black arm bands and stood for a moment of silence with the Mexican team in solidarity with the forest fire victims. The ceremony took place before the teams' match Sunday at the Confederations Cup tournament.

Coach Fernando Santos, Cristiano Ronaldo and the rest of the players released a statement saying "in this sad hour, we send our deepest sympathies to the families, friends and loved ones of the victims of the fires."

urn:contentItem:531G-3D21-DYTG-X31P-00000-00Smoke from forest fire hampers evacuation of Saskatchewan town2011-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A8Smoke from forest fire hampers evacuation of Saskatchewan townThe Canadian PressWOLLASTON LAKE, SASK.

Smoke from an out-of-control forest fire has closed the only way out for residents from a northern Saskatchewan community who have been told they need to leave.

Officials said the fire, which covered about five square kilometres, was burning next to the Wollaston Lake airport, which had to be closed. About 240 people from the hamlet and a nearby reserve were airlifted out before the air strip was shut down.

There is no road out of the community, which is home to about 1,400 people, and the lake is too frozen for a barge to operate.

Steve Roberts, executive director of wildfire management, said shifting winds were blowing smoke across the runway, which was reducing visibility.

Rescue co-ordinator Anne Robillard, who lives in Wollaston Lake, said the flames were getting close.

"The fire is less than a kilometre away," she said Wednesday. "The wind's shifting our way... and it's going to go directly to us."

Robillard said she was trying to remain calm even though the fire was advancing.

"Personally, I'm taking responsibility, so I'm not on the panicky side yet. I have to say that because I see the flames so close."

Roberts said officials hoped the winds would shift again and flights would resume.

For the time being, residents in the community, about 840 kilometres north of Saskatoon, were being sent to stay in buildings with air-conditioning.

The fire was first reported to Saskatchewan Environment on Monday. The evacuation order came down Tuesday.

The Wollaston Lake fire has closed the only way out for residents of a northern Saskatchewan community who have been ordered out of the area by the government. Government of Saskatchewan, The Canadian Press

urn:contentItem:4SP4-76N0-TX4V-K03X-00000-00Hundreds of Manitoba forest fire evacuees to return home by weekend2008-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSHundreds of Manitoba forest fire evacuees to return home by weekendKEVIN ROLLASONCP

ST. THERESA, Man. _ Hundreds of residents of St. Theresa Point will be back in their homes by the weekend after more than a week of being evacuated because of a forest fire.

Meanwhile, a poor visibility alert has been issued for another northern part of the province because of thick smoke.

Motorists are urged to use caution on Highway 6 approximately 60 kilometres north of Grand Rapids, for a two to three kilometre section.

Curtis Smith, executive director of the Manitoba Association of Native Fire Fighters, said health officials gave the green light Thursday for St. Theresa residents to return.

More than 660 people had been evacuated from the community to Winnipeg since last Wednesday because of the threat of the forest fire and then the health risk from blowing smoke.

Smith said arrangements are being made to get the evacuees on flights heading out Friday and Saturday.

Smith said they should know soon whether 70 people evacuated from Wasagamack at about the same time can return home.

Manitoba Conservation fire program manager Tom Mirus said fire crews are still battling the fires near the two communities, as well as two others near Sherridon and Grand Rapids.

Mirus said the fire crews still include more than 100 firefighters and two water bombers from Ontario and 28 firefighters from Alberta, but that could change depending on weather.

''If the rain comes to the north, we will release some of the out-of-province equipment, but that would depend on the amount of rainfall,'' he said.

Mirus said that up until Thursday, 190 forest fires have burned more than 65 square kilometres.

urn:contentItem:5G0P-FF41-JBVR-303J-00000-00Almost 200 personnel battling B.C. forest fire that premier calls 'alarming'2015-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisPRAIRIES/BCAlmost 200 personnel battling B.C. forest fire that premier calls 'alarming'Fire season starting early in B.C.: premierThe Canadian Press

VANCOUVER - British Columbia's premier is calling a wildfire that has already scorched more than 130 square kilometres in the central Interior "alarming," and is warning residents of a "bad forest fire season" ahead.

Christy Clark was in Prince George Friday to get an update on the Little Bobtail Lake fire, which was reported May 9.

By the afternoon, the Wildfire Management Branch was reporting that nearly 200 people, eight helicopters, 22 pieces of equipment and eight tankers were battling the blaze that had forced municipalities to issues evacuation orders and alerts that residents may have to leave at any moment.

"There has not been a fire this big, this early in the year since 1983, and this fire's bigger," said Clark. She called the fire "alarming" and said it was likely caused by humans.

Clark said the province experienced a dry winter and is expected to see a dry summer. She also noted the abundance of trees killed by pine beetles in the forests.

"The bad end of that is that we're going to have probably a very bad forest fire season," she said. "So people need to be really, really careful this year."

Bill Miller, chairman of the Regional District of Bulkley-Nechako, said local officials have placed about 700 to 800 residences west of Prince George under evacuation alert.

He said about 60 residences were placed under evacuation order, although most of those are seasonal homes.

The neighbouring Regional District of Fraser-Fort George issued evacuation orders to about 130 people last Sunday night and evacuation alerts to about 122 properties the next day, said information officer Renee McCloskey.

"You can see the smoke from town," she said from Prince George.

McCloskey said fire officials may upgrade the evacuation alerts to orders and they are preparing group accommodations.

"We do know that fires cost hundreds of millions of dollars," said Clark.

"It was $300 million dollars we spent last year putting out fires. If we keep on this track, it's going to be more this year. And, you know, British Columbians aren't giving us more money."

The Wildfire Management Branch was also reporting that two other "wildfires of note" had burned 250 and 83 hectares near Quesnel and Clearwater, respectively.

The Forests Ministry said small campfires are currently permitted throughout B.C., with the maximum allowable size of 0.5 metres wide by 0.5 metres high.

Almost half of all wildfires in the province are caused by people, and the Wildfire Management Branch said resources are unnecessarily tied up to deal with them.

Clark said people won't want to see another blaze like the Little Bobtail Lake fire and she urged everybody to be careful in the forests.

Note to readers: This is a corrected version. A previous story located evacuees east of Prince George.

urn:contentItem:5W4W-NH11-F103-301N-00000-00Parry Sound 33 impact, looking to summer 2019 in Parry Sound2019-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:43ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Parry Sound 33 impact, looking to summer 2019 in Parry Sound

PARRY SOUND -Parry Sound 33 isn't out of mind.

As summer starts unofficially this weekend, we revisit it and look forward to Summer 2019.

Parry Sound 33 was reported to the province's forest firefighters at 5:15 p.m. on Wednesday, July 18, 2018 when it was 53.8 hectares on Henvey Inlet First Nation, about 100 km north of Parry Sound. The next day it was 100 hectares in size. By the time Parry Sound 33 was considered under control, and then out on Oct. 31, 11,362 hectares were burnt leaving behind memories of Key River, French River and Henvey Inlet residents' evacuations and lost homes, plus lost tourism business for those on its border.

During Parry Sound 33, Britt was the command centre for firefighters and its department's members helped in the evacuations.

"With our emergency preparedness plan, it was a good working exercise. There were things we might have changed but we had a chance to exercise it and for all intents and purposes it went really well," said Britt fire chief Larry Olds.

The department is working to revamp the plan, based on lessons learned, to layout clear steps ahead of declaring a state of emergency. A state of emergency wasn't declared in Britt.

Parry Sound 33 has changed how some are approaching burning.

"People still have (the fire) on the back of their minds," said Olds. "I'm getting more phone calls this year: 'can we burn or should we burn?' They're more conscience now of burning than they were before...especially when they realize the cost of burning, if it gets out of hand that they could be on the hook for."

The fire had Bear Claw Tours business down 45 per cent from 2017 with people thinking it was in Parry Sound, the town. The good news is that so far his May to November season is starting off on the right foot, despite flooding in Muskoka that has his customers concerned trails here may be under water.

"First of all I have to dig myself out of the 45 per cent hole," said owner Andrew Ryeland. "That means paying back (debt), but I'm hopeful that we'll be able to do that. Unless something else happens, we should be fine."

If there is a forest fire in the District of Parry Sound of similar magnitude, he hopes it's named differently. Parry Sound 33 was the 33rd fire in Parry Sound District but it was confused with the Town of Parry Sound, a situation exasperated when a Toronto television show falsely reported Parry Sound was being evacuated.

In Ontario, the forest fire season starts in April.

In April 2018 the Parry Sound area had 90 mm of rain, 38.5 mm in May, 39.3mm in June and 7.3 mm in July. This year, there was 131.1 mm in April and on May 9, the forecast was up to 60 mm of rain.

Environment Canada weather preparedness meteorologist Peter Kimbell said there's no way of knowing if conditions will change and be closer to those of last year.

"I looked at the forecast for the summer, and really there's no signal," said Kimbell. "It could be anything."

Last year there were 1,300 forest fires in Ontario. Prior to that the 10-year average was 757. This year the first forest fire in this district, Parry Sound 1, was April 17.

The Forest Fire Info Map shows Parry Sound 1 was across the railway tracks that had been a line in the sand for those battling Parry Sound 33, and it was human caused.

"The amount and timing of precipitation is obviously the biggest factor that we see," said spokesperson Shayne McCool of the forest fire season. "When we see a long period without significant rain the vegetation has an opportunity to dry out and it can become more susceptible to fires."

Between April 2018 and March 2019 the province spent $212 million on fighting forest fires and brought in help from the U.S. and Mexico. The base budget this year is $69.8 million. Last month that difference had critics claiming the province had slashed funding.

"There have actually been no cuts to the forest fire fighting funding. Each year Ontario provides about $70 million to support the front line efforts of fighting forest fires. That funding is reevaluated by the Ontario government as the season unfolds," said McCool.

To help cut down the number of fires humans cause the public is reminded to never leave a camp fire unattended and ensure it's completely out.

The cause of Parry Sound 33 was given as a disabled vehicle. No charges under the Forest Fires Prevention Act were laid.

Sidebar:

Story behind the story

Last year's massive fire took the community by storm. Could it happen again? With summer 2019 just around the corner our reporter's mind turned what could be ahead of us.

Three people were killed and 21 injured, officials said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Associated Press</p></bodyText></section><p>Twenty-two vehicles were involved in the crash, including a tractor-trailer carrying acid, said Lieutenant Ken Knowles, spokesman for the Florida highway patrol.</p><p>The acid was contained within the truck and never posed a danger, he said.</p><p>Knowles blamed the pileup on a blaze in Osceola National Park about 15 kilometres away.</p><p>"The low visibility was a result of the forest fire," Knowles said.</p><p>The injured were taken to hospitals. Rhonda Sherrod of Shands Hospital said her facility had treated 14 victims, with injuries ranging from minor to critical. Three of the more seriously injured were airlifted to other hospitals, she said.</p><p>The accident occurred on Interstate 10 shortly before 8 a.m. Officials closed nearly 30 kilometres of the highway from Lake City to Live Oak, which is about 120 kilometres east of Tallahassee.</p><p>Because of so much twisted wreckage, it took several hours for authorities to determine how many vehicles were involved. At least five trucks could be seen jackknifed in the wreckage.</p><p>Murel McDonald, Suwanee County emergency services manager, said when he arrived at the scene, smoke from the forest fire blanketed the ground. The fire was intentionally set, officials have said.</p><p>McDonald said he has requested satellite imagery from the state to determine the precise cause of the crash.</p><p>Erik Gebauer, of Melbourne, Fla., said he was driving a car that slid under a tractor trailer.</p><p>"I don't understand how I lived through that," said Gebauer, his voice shaking.
